etymology.description: 黍(黍) (shǔ, "glutinous millet") + 口(口) (kǒu, "mouth") -> millet used for liquor -> 甘(甘) (gān, "sweet") replaced 口, indicating sweetness -> 禾(禾) + 曰(曰) final form
etymology.interpretation: The character 香(xiāng) originated from showcasing millet as a beverage ingredient, hinting at the fragrant nature of such products. Over time, the components evolved to stress the sweet and fragrant aspect, becoming 禾 and 曰 to convey aroma.

examples.chinese: 花儿散发出香气(花兒散發出香氣)。
examples.english: The flowers emit a fragrant scent.

examples.chinese: 这汤闻起来很香(這湯聞起來很香)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè tāng wén qǐlái hěn xiāng.

examples.chinese: 她的香水味迷人(她的香水味迷人)，让人陶醉(讓人陶醉)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de xiāngshuǐ wèi mírén, ràng rén táozuì.
examples.english: Her perfume is enchanting, making people intoxicated.
